author: raulj
content: This is not exactly a cap in the traditional sense of the word (I assume a cap meaning a maximum allowed). It is more like some are active, some are dormant, and there is switching between them after certain numbers of epochs

author: raulj
content: The actual cap in the protocol is set to be a massive number

author: mrabino1
content: interesting... curious what is the advantage of a hardcap over letting the market decide how much ETH to stake (knowing full well the return degrades w/ more validators)?  in all scenarios (that I can think of) the end nodes running the beaconchain and a validator would have to track active and dormant validators (so still memory intensive)... so it would seem the economics degrade if more than 1MM validators show-up..  curious why the hard limit?

author: jgm
content: Network resources to transport attestations, CPU resources to aggregate attestations.

author: mrabino1
content: curious, are those two items not set to also scale with time? e.g. will the technology outpace the possible constraint?

author: protolambda
content: It's more of a safety bound for resource consumption, which could be increased if the technology keeps up with the validator set growth.
